Article.ArticleTitle: Comparison of ozone-based AOPs on the removal of organic matter from the secondary biochemical effluent of coking wastewater.

AbstractText: Advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) based on ozone are gaining continuously growing popularity in wastewater treatment. This study explored the treatment of coking wastewater using a combination of ozonation (O<sub>3</sub>), ultraviolet (UV), and hydrogen peroxide (H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>) process expressed by % chemical oxygen demand (COD) removal, % total organic carbon (TOC), % UV<sub>254</sub>, % fluorescence intensity removal and its electrical energy consumption. The obtained results demonstrated that, the combination of O<sub>3</sub>, UV, and H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> which is denoted by O<sub>3</sub>/UV/H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> in this study achieved great success in COD removal (92.08%), TOC removal (78.25%), and reduction of fluorescence intensity (99.82%). Compared with the O<sub>3</sub> and O<sub>3</sub>/UV processes, O<sub>3</sub>/UV/H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> improved the COD removal by approximately 54-69% and 38-51%, respectively. In addition, the energy consumption was reduced by 53-67%. The TOC removal rate in the effluent ranged 71% and 83%, while the UV<sub>254</sub> removal rate was up to 90%. The fluorescence spectroscopy showed that the O<sub>3</sub>/UV/H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> combination process reduced the fluorescence intensity by almost 97% within 10 min. Furthermore, the total polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) concentration in the effluent was less than 10μg/L (removal efficiency > 80%) and the most toxic benzo(a)pyrene (BaP) was less than 0.03 μg/L (0.018μg/L). In addition, the energy consumption of the O<sub>3</sub>/UV/H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> process was 53-67% lower than those of O<sub>3</sub> and O<sub>3</sub>/UV processes. Furthermore, the energy consumption was 80.26 kWh m<sup>-3</sup> after 60 min of reaction time when the COD (69.3 mg/L) met the standard discharge. Finally, the O<sub>3</sub>/UV/H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> process could be an effective method for improving the mineralisation of refractory organic matter.
